text: we are now going to solve another
problem in subnetting let's see the
question now the question is if a class
b network on the internet has a subnet
what is the maximum number of hosts per
network or per subnet
and this question was asked in gate
computer science in the year 2008
options are given option a1022
option b1023 option c2046
and option d2047 before going into the
solution page we need to understand how
this subnet mask is achieved that is
this is a classless subnet mask from
which class this classless subnet mask
was achieved please note it is given in
the question so actually it was a class
b network on the internet but it is now
having a classless subnet mask we need
this information because we don't know
whether a class way network was
submitted or class b network was
subnetted because we need to figure out
how many octets are affected with the
bit modifications right
let's now dive into the solution page
we know the subnet mask which is given
in the question is 255.255.248.0
and we will convert this into binary in
order to explore things and solve the
problem so when we convert this into
binary we will be getting all once in
the first two octets because the first
two octets in the decimal representation
of the subnet mask is 255 in the first
two octanes so we'll be having obviously
all once in the first two octaves and
then for two for eight it is five ones
followed by triple zero and then the
last octet is zero so in binary all bits
are zero in the fourth octet and we will
now figure out how many hosts are
possible how many networks are possible
now if this is a class a subnet mask and
then if it is submitted then we need to
take these three octets why because a
class a subnet mask means the first
octet remains unchanged but in the
question it is given as a class b subnet
mask right because the first two octets
are fixed from the original subnet mask
we are just deriving the entire contents
in the first two octets to the new
subnet mask so obviously these two
octets are not changed in the new subnet
mask so ultimately we are focusing on
the next two octaves so we can easily
witness that the changes only in these
two octets so how many number of ones is
there it is five ones in this new subnet
mask so five ones in the new subnet mask
says two power 5 number of networks are
possible so 2 power 5 means 32 subnets
are possible and how many number of
hosts per network possible so out of
these 16 bits five bits are reserved for
one right that's the number of subnets
and we have 11 bits here
so 2 power 11 hosts are possible but if
it is an ip address we can have 2 power
11 ip addresses are possible but we
can't assign all 2 power 11 ip addresses
to the host because the first ip address
and the last ip address are not used for
the host obviously we need to reduce 2
from it so 2 power 11 is 2048 and
obviously we are going to reduce 2 from
it why because the first address at the
last address cannot be assigned to the
host so
2048-2 hosts possible per subnet because
the first address is the network address
and the last address is the broadcast
address which are not used for the host
so therefore the maximum number of hosts
per subnet is
2046. we will see where is the answer in
the options
it's option c 2046.
